reviewText:
Shadow Puppeteer is a good game to play local co-op with your daughter.  If you don't have a daughter, I really suggest investing in one, as they are really useful to have around.  I've seen some criticism of Shadow Puppeteer as not being a good single player game, and that may be completely true, but my recommendation is based entirely on the co-op experience.

First thing to do here is get the obvious comparison out of the way.  Shadow Puppeteer gets compared to Contrast, but that seems to be based on the general premise.  Shadow Puppeteer is no Contrast.  If you want a really good single player game and don't have Contrast, get that.  It is very cool.  But if you want a good local co-op game to play with your daughter, and I'm assuming you have acquired one by this point based on my previous suggestion, get Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light.  After you have finished that, get Shadow Puppeteer.

Damn
recommended: "This sounds like rather faint praise."  I understand it might sound like I'm not even recommending this game
hoursPlayed: but all I'm really saying is that while Shadow Puppeteer isn't the best co-op experience out there

votesFunny: so that no matter what they do

column19: thereby alienating the daughter that you rely on to play co-op games.\n\nIt's not always easy maintaining a balance between video games and daughters and cats

Which would you not want to live without?

I know that for myself

reviewText:
Shadow Puppeteer is a beautiful, unique and interesting platformer. It's great fun to play with a friend, and was to me surprisingly fluent single player as well. Controlling both characters at the same time creates for a very cool dynamic. I adore the art style, and I think the cutscenes are fantastic. The music is also really good, and creates a very nice atmosphere.

Yes, the game has some flaws, but to me personally they're very minor. Nothing that you shouldn't expect from a small indie game like this. It's all a part of the charm, and it just adds to the character. Like how something home made might not come in fancy wrappings, but has a lot more soul and heart than a big commercial product could ever achieve.

It's a beautiful little indie title, and I recommend everyone to play it.

reviewText:
I've tried this game both as co-op and single player and even though the game shines brightest when playing co-op, it baffles my mind how so many dismiss the single player as unplayable. The closest comparison I could find is that controlling both characters at the same time is like playing an instrument (piano, guitar, etc); you have to disconnect your hands from each other to play them right. It's not something many people can pick up instantly, but after a bit of practice anyone can get into the groove.

Co-op is, as I've said, the mode I enjoyed the most (and from what I can tell it's designed around). It's probably best to see the single player as an added challenge extending the co-op part of the game. And with all these local co-op action games coming out it's good to have a puzzle game to chill out with.

The devs have also been updating with bug fixes and gameplay tweaks which is great.

If you play on keyboard I would highly recommend you remap the keys to something you feel is comfortable. But since this is a platformer you should play it with a controller, like all platformers should.

reviewText:
This game has a cute idea, but fails badly on execution. The basic premise is that you control a little boy and his shadow, who are chasing after a man who has stolen everyone else's shadows. There's no dialogue in the cutscenes, but it's pretty simple and easy to follow the very thin plot. The core of the game is the platforming, and this is where it has trouble. The boy moves through a 3D environment, and the shadow moves across the wall or floor in a 2D environment. This provides for some cool ways to twist the traditional platforming concepts, as he must stay on shadows, and they can be manipulated in interesting ways.

Right off the bat, you get the feeling the game is unpolished, as the boy's legs don't consistently animate. He just glides around for a while, then his legs will sometimes start moving. The jumping sequences are sometimes pretty frustrating, but what makes them worse is that sometimes you will encounter weird clipping glitches where the boy will pass through ostensibly solid surfaces. Sometimes this helps, like when you can move through a wall and get past a tough spot, but sometimes he'll just fall through the floor into the abyss. There was one spot in the game where I got stuck in a loop where the boy would die for no reason, and immediately respawn, only to die again. There was no way to get out of this other than to restart the level. And that was about halfway through relatively long level, so I lost a good amount of progress.

There are also some bad design choices, like the energy line connecting the boy and the shadow. If they get too far apart, they apparently die and you have to start over at the last checkpoint. This is annoying enough as something to constantly worry about, but in one leve, where the surfaces the shadow is standing on are moving great distances side to side, it's just about game breaking, because it's extremely tough to keep the boy and the shadow close enough together to avoid insta-death and having to go back to the last checkpoint yet again.

So in summary, neat idea marred by bad design and sloppy execution. There's no way this is worth the price they're asking. Give it a miss.

reviewText: A story about a boy and his shadow, this game makes it's players totally immersed in everything that's going on. The puzzles are actually a little tricky at times and are a lot of fun to solve. I find myself being connected to the other player on a different level, since everything depends on total co-operation, and because you always have to be close to eachother, or you die. And the way the game looks is really charming in it's own kind of way!\n\nI recommend this game to anyone out there that needs something to play locally, since you can beat it in a single session. I also joined a couple buddies to play through this game at Gigacon 2014, and i had a lot of time to observe it. We beat it in a single sitting, for about 3-4 hours, and we had an absolute blast. It had a really artistic feel and is something i have been looking for for a while.

reviewText:
An interesting idea poorly executed. You may draw comparisons to games like Contrast. And to make this short just play that instead.

If you're looking for a competent cute, slightly whimsical aesthetic co-op platformer this is it. If you want all that and one that plays well. Look elsewhere. I'd also suggest playing with another actual human if you still insist on playing this. Its not offensively bad. Its more disappointingly bad.

Brothers : Tales of two sons comes to mind for its obvious inspiration. However that game is designed so well that playing both characters as one person is not only easy its required. This game on the other hand leaves something to be desired at every turn. Level design and puzzle design are strange. Sudden juts of shadow will force the shadow character into strange places making jumping difficult to judge. There are numerous “move this box”, “hold this thing there” for other character to make a jump sequences. The only problem is its not always clear what you can jump on as its a side scrolling camera in a 3D space (but only for the human character). There is also some double minecart riding while being chased action.

Not to mention the UI for such things requires the player to stand in a very specific spot to interact with the object. Making a confusing puzzle that much more frustrating. I should also mention there is zero indication of the fact you must press a separate button for interaction with the minecart on the shadows behalf.

There is no dialogue or voice acting, which definitely isn’t a complaint. This actually adds to the rather whimsical feel of the aesthetic within the game and cut-scenes. Which are rather well done and is my favorite part of the game.

I'd say play this with a young one. As its bare bones its still playable and very nice looking. But if not. Just avoid it.

EDIT AFTER AN UPDATE
There was an update after my initial experience with the game. It does address some of these issues but not all. It is slightly more playable in essence but I still cannot reccommend the game as a whole.

reviewText:
I got this game not really knowing what I was in for. Once I figured out the controlls the game play was smooth.
Pros: Music is amazing, different enough to be new and unique, but not too crazy that it distracts from the gameplay.
Game play overall is smooth and the shadows actually respond to simple shadow physics
The game looksa amazing with all of the color schemes and animation style. If you like art, then you will like this.
The puzzles are difficult enough to not make the game an absolute breeze, but are not impossible to figure out.
Playing this with the co-op option is a lot of fun especially when you and the other person actually rely heavily on eachother.
Cons: There is one little glitch where you can stand in the wall. You don't skip anything, and you don't get stuck but it is just there.
I say getting this game is totally worth it.

reviewText: Shadow puppeteer is without a doubt a unique co-op experience that requires not only good teamwork but a well working imagination to work through the various puzzles. It paces nicely, each level feels unique and never are you in a position that you grind the same impossible puzzle for nearly an hour.\n\nIt's a rather short game, a friend and I completed it from start to finish in just under three hours. Though I don't necessarily see it as a downside, as loca co-op games require a time investment for both parties that is usually hard to come by. A game that spans this length means as we have done, you can sit your buddy down and finish it in one go.

Although it has some very interesting ideas and a cute aesthetic, it was simply too buggy for me. My laptop usually runs modern games at 60fps and yet this game ran poorly, to say the least. I got 5 fps at times, which made it almost unbeatable, specially playing solo. The camera angles are so bad implemented that I just kept falling everywhere. Sometimes, there’s a small delay after  pressing a key and the action taking place, which basically results in the little dude suddenly deciding to commit suicide instead of jumping over a small gap… and also in the player raging uncontrollably as the screen fades to black.

I can tell how much effort and care the developers have put into this game, but playing Shadow Puppeteer felt like a chore to me. Something I had to finish, but not something I was enjoying along the way. Maybe if it hadn’t run so poorly… or maybe if I had played it with a friend…  Anyway, this game is definitely a pass, but not something I’d recommend after all the problems I had with it. As a positive note, the feeling I had when seeing a kite after beating a hard part of the game was quite real. Oh, and the last two bosses’ stages, where there are no kites (save points)… Yeah, well that took a while.

Good luck with future projects, Sarepta Studio!  Please, take this as a constructive criticism. I will definitely give the studio another chance when your next game comes out!

reviewText:
Consider clicking here if you like(d) this review: http://rgz.ca/gaming/shadow-puppeteer-review-squandered-potential/

The link has pretty pictures!

Note: There are minor spoilers in the paragraphs preceded with a *. These are unavoidable as I explain my frustrations with the game but, in case you want to avoid them, the note is there.

Nothing frustrates me more than a game than a game with a good idea that doesn't use it to its fullest or, possibly, manages to make the entire idea frustrating in execution. Shadow Puppeteer is one of those games. I'm getting ahead of myself, though. Let me explain what the game is all about.

In Shadow Puppeteer, you are separated from your shadow by the titular shadow puppeteer. He plays his creepy little song and split - there goes your shadow, disconnected from you. However, for some reason or other, he fails to capture your shadow and now you must go on an adventure, chasing after him, to get your shadow reconnected to you.

On the surface, it's a game not unlike Contrast, where you are constantly manipulating both a character in the 3D world and the 2D shadow world. The big difference is that, unlike Contrast, you're controlling them both at the same time. Now, I played the game with Kat in co-op for its entirety and I can't even begin to describe how frustrating the single-player setup seems like it would be. Just having looked at it, it looked nightmarish, controlling one character with each joystick and using buttons on the same side of the controller as the joystick, except for one button which is placed on the opposite side of the controller for the boy. It doesn't look fun. The game was clearly built for co-op. Which, by the way, the game doesn't even fully explain its controls. It gives you instructional videos on how to play - without the controls attached. I had to read an external guide to figure some of the controls out, mostly just figuring them out by frantically pressing buttons until something happened. Oh, and for the shadow, there's a dedicated hold on to/let go of mine cart" button.

Playing as the boy is pretty simple. You walk around
recommended: you jump across the occasional rooftop. The boy's playing experience is exponentially simpler than the shadow's despite having an extra dimension. There are numerous times that his role is relegated to handing the shadow different objects that are collected over the course of the game. The shadow
voteText: is required to manipulate all sorts of objects using only their shadows
commentsCount: as well as being the one in mortal danger during boss fights.\n\nThese puzzles are rather clever at times. Some of them get a bit repetitive
column16: almost all of the game's puzzles making use of the same four or five objects
column17: with those that aren't being very simple
column18: but there are some in there that are very clever. There are even those that aren't clever that will make you "ooo" and "aaah" at the uniqueness of it and the fact that they got it working at all. I was pleasantly surprised with a number of them. I was equally disappointed with repetitiveness.\n\nSome of the puzzles get extremely frustrating
column19: though. About halfway through the game

column22: which should burn him up but
column24: suddenly gains the ability to orbit around them. These circular lights are incredibly finicky
column25: sometimes requiring several jumps in the exact same spot to get the game to trigger the switch to another light. Other times
column26: these lights caused weird issues with gravity that shot the shadow upwards
column27: into some part of the level or other
column29: these lights were a major nuisance.\n\nThose weren't the only nuisance
column30: though. Despite having a simpler play experience
column31: the boy can be very difficult to maneuver due to poor viewing angles. I can't tell you how many times I fell off a cliff because the viewing angle threw my depth perception off. There were even times that the game obscured gaps in fences with the viewing angle
column32: making it look like they were connected when they weren't
column33: and I went off the edge.\n\nI also was largely disappointed in level design as a whole. The sections of the game that I could really consider to be clever were all too brief. The levels that they were part of lasted a significantly smaller amount of time than those that rehashed old design ideas. The levels themselves were also significantly smaller than the levels providing rehashes
column34: usually being just large enough to cover the unique puzzle whereas the rehashed segments would have lots of extra running room.\n\nBut that isn't even the most frustrating part. The game focuses even more on its most frustrating parts than it does on rehashes. The longest segments of the game are the seemingly inevitable chase scenes

They're all frustrating mine cart segments that are a bit temperamental at times.\n\nThe mine segment I had issues with was this segment that required the player to jump from one elevator of sorts to another when they came into close proximity of each other. It required you to do this for nigh on ten different elevators in a row

column43: only the circular shadows aren't the ones manipulating the gravity; the object in between them is. When the gravity combined with the slippery nature of the circular objects are working against you - I cannot tell you how many times it took to get the shadow to make a jump onto one of these objects that he clearly could make because he kept slipping off - it makes even the simplest tasks difficult. But then you also have to make use of the bomb powerup
column44: which...isn't affected by the same gravity that you are

And then these circular platforms start moving.\n\n*But the battle doesn't end there. It has another entire segment where the boss now shoots projectiles at you; projectiles that are twice your size and lock onto your position. Oh

column49: occasionally dying when these projectiles hit the other side of them
column50: and the depth perception issues that the boy has and you have one incredibly frustrating boss fight that already outstayed its welcome with the first half.\n\nSo
column51: if you're looking for a unique co-op experience and don't mind a lot of minor frustrations that build into a larger amount of frustration
column52: you might consider Shadow Puppeteer. If you're not looking for a co-op experience

column54: that's the thing. The game is frustrating. There are bad design decisions and minor issues all over the place that cause this frustration. It had potential but when an entire hour of the three and a half hour playtime you have is spent replaying the final"

A wonderful and very charming little game.  If it is ever cheaper than 4 bucks I would highly recommend purchasing this one.  If you are a fan of simple and amusing puzzle platformers this is most certainly a game up your alley.

Pros;
- Very attractive art style that seems to be a blend of Tim Burton and Wallace and Gromit
- Simplistic puzzles that do not fail to elicit a smile
- A wonderful co-op experience
- If you are looking for a challenge you can play this game solo
- Music was a definite plus

Cons;
- Very short game length and most certainly not worth at full price
- Controls can be a bit spotty here and there
- The game would sometimes slow down or get a little choppy

All-in-all if this game is on a large sale you should totally snatch this one up.

Very fun co-op.

I love this game. Super fun puzzle game where eyou and your shadow have to stop the shadow puppeteer. You control both characters or you can do co-op which would be much easier. Kind like Ibb and Obb in a way. Loading times are slow between scenes and menus. I wish it had online co-op.
Liked it a lot in co-op so far.

Actually pretty fun game to play with a friend from the coach with a gamepads. It's not that long and it's pretty easy but that just makes it perfect for people who are new to gaming (like kids or your girlfriend). If you are planning to play this alone I would definitely recommend to skip this game otherwise buy it and have fun until it lasts.

I love playing cooperative videogames. They let you test your teamwork and communication skills. Its great way to pass the time with friends and family. Its not very often a co-op game really catches my attention and as online gaming continues to grow local co-op is becoming limited. So when me and my sister played through Shadow Puppeteer over the last couple weeks I was extremely impressed. This is a great, stand-out, co-op experience and developers should be taking notes.

In shadow puppeteer your character becomes aware of a man stealing everyone's shadows. He fails to capture your shadow but he does manage to separate it from your body. Now you and your shadow must help each other traverse different obstacles as you chase down the shadow puppeteer.

The first thing you'll notice about Shadow Puppeteer is the asymmetrical game-play. The boy lives in three dimensions where as the shadow lives on a 2D plane. The shadow needs to keep on top of other shadows to keep from falling out of the world. The boy has to help move objects around to help the shadow navigate. The shadow also can help out since he has the ability to reach places the boy can't.

You and your partner really need to cooperate if you want to progress. Both characters share an equal load of the work. This isn't the kind of game where one player can just compensate for the other. There are challenging situations that requires both players to be in sync and they often take several tries to complete. Its feels extremely rewarding when you finally succeed together.

The game is not perfect. The physics are touchy and aren't very predictable. Also the game isn't particularly long. This all being said it was a very fulfilling experience. If you're looking for co-op games for PC and have a couple 360 controllers I highly recommend it. This is what co-op games are all about. I really hope we continue to see more games like it.

Excellent game for two players, the mechanics are easy to learn but challenging to master.\nThe scenario is interesting and immersive, graphics are great and the challenges are progressivly more difficult.

Shadow Puppeteer is a fantastic game that's meant for a great co-op experience. I first completed the game on Wii U on my own and was that a challenge. Plenty of anger moments especially towards boss scenes haha. Got the chance to play with a friend and it makes the game so much easier. The game is single player is really a bonus to players who dare to complete it on their own as it is not easy. The game is stunning to look at and the music is fantastic from start to finish. I wish there was more games like this on any console. There is also plenty of Orbs to be collected which will unlock brilliant artwork and songs to listen to on the menu. If I was to quickly review this, I would give it an 8.5/85% rating. A massive congrats to Sarepta Studio on their PC and Wii U debut and hope they continue to make more great, co-op games for everyone to enjoy. Support the smaller" indie companies that help shape the industry today! :)"
Excellent two player local coop game!
Fun game, neat story, but play it in co-op or you'll go crazy.  At times it can be difficult to control two characters at the same time.

A lovely twist on the traditional co-op platformer.  While it has a single player mode, I wouldn't recommend it, co-op is where this game shines.  While enjoyable, there are a few niggling problems that keep the game from being perfect.  The controls are, at times, sluggish.  This makes some of the more precise puzzles a bit challenging to complete and can cause them to feel tedious at times.\nOverall a great game with a few kinks that one hopes can be worked out in future updates.  3.5/5

The game itself is fun and enjoyable with fable-like graphics. The problem is with the game mechanics. reviewText: Actually pretty fun game to play with a friend from the coach with a gamepads. It's not that long and it's pretty easy but that just makes it perfect for people who are new to gaming (like kids or your girlfriend). If you are planning to play this alone I would definitely recommend to skip this game otherwise buy it and have fun until it lasts.
Fun game, neat story, but play it in co-op or you'll go crazy.  At times it can be difficult to control two characters at the same time.
Liked it a lot in co-op so far.

Shadow Puppeteer is a fantastic game that's meant for a great co-op experience. I first completed the game on Wii U on my own and was that a challenge. Plenty of anger moments especially towards boss scenes haha. Got the chance to play with a friend and it makes the game so much easier. The game is single player is really a bonus to players who dare to complete it on their own as it is not easy. The game is stunning to look at and the music is fantastic from start to finish. I wish there was more games like this on any console. There is also plenty of Orbs to be collected which will unlock brilliant artwork and songs to listen to on the menu. If I was to quickly review this, I would give it an 8.5/85% rating. A massive congrats to Sarepta Studio on their PC and Wii U debut and hope they continue to make more great, co-op games for everyone to enjoy. Support the smaller" indie companies that help shape the industry today! :)"

I love playing cooperative videogames. They let you test your teamwork and communication skills. Its great way to pass the time with friends and family. Its not very often a co-op game really catches my attention and as online gaming continues to grow local co-op is becoming limited. So when me and my sister played through Shadow Puppeteer over the last couple weeks I was extremely impressed. This is a great, stand-out, co-op experience and developers should be taking notes.

In shadow puppeteer your character becomes aware of a man stealing everyone's shadows. He fails to capture your shadow but he does manage to separate it from your body. Now you and your shadow must help each other traverse different obstacles as you chase down the shadow puppeteer.

The first thing you'll notice about Shadow Puppeteer is the asymmetrical game-play. The boy lives in three dimensions where as the shadow lives on a 2D plane. The shadow needs to keep on top of other shadows to keep from falling out of the world. The boy has to help move objects around to help the shadow navigate. The shadow also can help out since he has the ability to reach places the boy can't.

You and your partner really need to cooperate if you want to progress. Both characters share an equal load of the work. This isn't the kind of game where one player can just compensate for the other. There are challenging situations that requires both players to be in sync and they often take several tries to complete. Its feels extremely rewarding when you finally succeed together.

The game is not perfect. The physics are touchy and aren't very predictable. Also the game isn't particularly long. This all being said it was a very fulfilling experience. If you're looking for co-op games for PC and have a couple 360 controllers I highly recommend it. This is what co-op games are all about. I really hope we continue to see more games like it.

Excellent game for two players, the mechanics are easy to learn but challenging to master.\nThe scenario is interesting and immersive, graphics are great and the challenges are progressivly more difficult.

Played through it with my girlfriend on a Sunday afternoon. It took about 4 hours, but around two hours of that was bashing our heads against a wall on the very last boss, not seeing the one little thing we needed to interact with- I get the feeling this might not have been extensively playtested from a couch 15 feet away & in daylight.

I really like the core mechanic, and it's done very well (though maybe not flawlessly). But where this game really shines is in playing it alongside somebody you trust. I've had very few co-op experiences I've enjoyed as much and would not hesitate to mention this game in the same breath as Portal 2.

It's a short game that probably costs too much relative to its length, and which completely falls apart at the final boss... on multiple levels. But playing through everything up to that boss was a fantastic experience and made our day. I wish there were more co-op puzzle games like this in the world.
Really interesting game with nice mechanics..  but really short!
This is a very cool very creative game.  Love the graphics style and the level design/ shadow mechanic makes for some interesting fun puzzles.
